<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 155, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 89]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 133, 561, 151]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 165, 240, 182]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 194, 384, 212]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 212, 581, 247]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 271, 228, 288]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 291, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 345, 495, 380]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 410, 384, 427]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 432, 534, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 488, 336, 504]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 509, 428, 579]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 610, 594, 628]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 156, 660]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 670, 583, 720]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 765, 242, 782]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 791, 594, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C\] \[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 416, 102]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{2 + \sin 3x}{x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 119, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
Show that the exact value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{6}\) can be written as \(\frac{k}{\left(\frac{\pi}{6} + 1\right)^2}\) , where \(k\) is an integer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 140, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 146, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 700, 534]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal to the curve at the point where \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 593, 102]]<|/det|>
Find rational values \(a\) and \(b\) such that \(\frac{a}{\sqrt{5} + 2} + \frac{b}{\sqrt{5} - 2} = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 484, 96]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = 3\tan^{2}x\) for \(0^{\circ}< x< 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 675, 129]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = m\tan x\sec^2 x\) where \(m\) is an integer to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 554, 440]]<|/det|>
Find all values of \(x\) such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = 3\sec x\cos \sec x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 764, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(m\) for which the line \(y = mx - 2\) does not touch or cut the curve

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 87, 299, 106]]<|/det|>
\(y = (m + 1)x^{2} + 8x + 1.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 893, 92]]<|/det|>
Use logarithms to solve the following equation, giving your answer correct to 1 decimal place.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 100, 566, 120]]<|/det|>
\[5^{x - 2} = 3\times 2^{2x + 3}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 411, 146, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 411, 566, 432]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\log_3 (y^2 + 11) - 2 = \log_3 (v - 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 598, 90]]<|/det|>
Marc chooses 5 people from 4 men, 4 women and 2 children.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 485, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that Marc can do this

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 364, 152]]<|/det|>
if there are no restrictions,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 146, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 376, 292]]<|/det|>
if at least 2 men are chosen,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 273, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 144, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 667, 523]]<|/det|>
if at least 1 man, at least 1 woman and at least 1 child are chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 757, 89]]<|/det|>
**DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS PART OF THE QUESTION.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 415, 120]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 87, 841, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 539, 342]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{5}{x} + x^{2} - x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 144, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 350, 895, 371]]<|/det|>
Find, in the form \(y = mx + c\), the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point where \(x = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 809, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area enclosed by the curve, the \(x\)-axis, and the lines \(x = 1\) and \(x = 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 78, 104, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 777, 101]]<|/det|>
The volume, \(V,\) of a cone with base radius \(r\) and vertical height \(h\) is given by \(\frac{1}{3}\pi r^2h.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 92, 792, 116]]<|/det|>
The curved surface area of a cone with base radius \(r\) and slant height \(l\) is given by \(\pi r l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 125, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
A cone has base radius \(r \mathrm{cm}\), vertical height \(h \mathrm{cm}\) and volume \(V \mathrm{cm}^3\). The curved surface area of the cone is \(4\pi \mathrm{cm}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 170, 144, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 359, 195]]<|/det|>
Show that \(h^2 = \frac{16}{r^2} - r^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 920, 192]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 621, 144, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 618, 393, 644]]<|/det|>
Show that \(V = \frac{\pi}{3}\sqrt{16r^2 - r^6}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Given that \(r\) can vary and that \(V\) has a maximum value, find the value of \(r\) that gives the maximum volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
